data.title: Finally had to try crawfish...
data.text: After living in Texas for 12 years and NEVER having tried crawfish, I gave in. Cajun Tailgators truck was in McKinney, TX for the Krewe of Barkus in McKinney and I had the Crawfish Pistolette - a hollowed-out roll that is then fried and filled with cheesy crawfish etoufee. It was the best thing I had eaten in a long, long time (their cajun fries are good, too!). So I started following Cajun Tailgators on Instagram where I learned they had a brick & mortar location in downtown Plano, and I didn't have to hunt for the truck to see where they'd be in Dallas next! I was stoked. I took my wife and kids - my daughter loved the Pistolette, too. My wife and son had the red beans and rice with andouille sausage. We finished with beignets. It's a small eatery, but everything is made fresh. I like the atmosphere; it felt like Louisiana (to me, as a non-native having only visited NOLA briefly). I can't wait to go back. My wife and son - this kind of food isn't their thing - but I have a place to take my daughter for the next crawfish boil and some delicious red beans and rice.

data.title: Worth a fun weekend sidetrip to historic downtown Plano
data.text:
Came for take out of craw fish etoufee and pistolettes and well worth the trip.  I dined on left overs for three days and it tasted as good as the first day.  While not as spicy as I hoped and without any hot sauce to fire it up, I was still pleased with the outcome. To be transparent, I have not been to the territory so my lack of a 'local' exierience may just taint the review - so keep this in mind.
I sat outside on a warm Spring day and the cook himself came out to deliver my lunches.  The service is definitely a plus.

data.title: Stopped by for a casual Saturday evening meal.
data.text:
Our nephew suggested Cajun Tailgators for dinner one weekend. We checked out the web to see what this place was all about, to see their menu and to check out recent reviews. We were pleased to see the place is a small, casual eatery with a unique Cajun-inspired menu. The menu is large enough that anyone should be able to find something they like. Our experience was great. 

When we arrived we went right up to the counter (this is a place where you order from the color-filled chalkboard behind the front counter, you pay and they bring your food to you), we asked for recommendations; the helpful employee recommended the gumbo, boudin balls, crawfish platter or the crawfish etouffee. The three of us ordered all that plus a salad and red beans and rice. Everything was very good but was spicy. Of course cajun food is typically spicy. The boudin balls reminded me of pepper balls I used to get 30 years ago in Denton; they were a nice surprise. We decided to add beignets. They were fresh, hot and hit the spot.

The dining room is small and consists of only a few tables - 20 or so people would fill the place up. Outside the have a side patio that can seat another 10 or so. We chose to sit outside and enjoy the cool March evening. On the patio are two pickup truck tailgates mounted to the building's outside wall and which serve as counter height tables - pretty cool.

We will certainly go back. We have already recommended the place to a half dozen people today.

data.title: Very good crawfish boil in this "hidden" gem
data.text: We went with another family for some crawfish boil to Cajun Tailgators.  Place it very cozy but 13 lbs of crawfish later, we all went home satisfied.  Staff is very nice and is extremely accommodating to our party of 11.  Love it!!  Will definitely come back for more.

data.title: Great Food, but inconsistent.
data.text: Most of the time this is a FANTASTIC place - but every now and then the food is WAY over spiced - almost not edible.  Seems like they don't have recipes.  I highly recommend any of their crawfish entrees - but ask in advance if they are SPICY today.

data.title: Decent Gumbo
data.text: My daughter liked the gumbo, but my fried catfish/fried shrimp plate was NOT good. Apparently my husband also liked the po'boys.

data.title: Awesome Cajun experience!
data.text:
We decided to do a menu sample to decide our favorites - and guess what - they're all our faves!  

Started with crawfish pistolettes, red beans and rice, fried crawfish tails.  Moved on to crawfish etoufee and blackened catfish with jambalaya!  Finished with the most amazing bread pudding full of coconut and nuts!!

All food was true to the Cajun tradition, staff was pleasant and helpful with suggestions - and byob made an evening on the patio a hit!

data.title: "Tastes Like Home"
data.text: We were 3 couples trying a new place.  We found a Cajun gem!  The crawfish pistolette is a must; it is delicious!  So are the seafood platter, gumbo, jambalaya, bread pudding, and the beignets.  It's BYOB with a quaint dining area packed with great flavors.  My friend, a Louisiana native said with a big smile, "It tastes like home!"

data.title: Delicious find
data.text: Terrific assortment of cajun specialities.  At employees request I tried the crawfish pistolette - absolutely delicious.  Even their basic salad was wonderful.  My teenage son LOVED the crawfish platter.  Don't miss this place.

data.title: Loved it!
data.text:
Always on the look out for good cajun food and seems I have found it! I knew if the food truck but didn't know they had a store front. My wife and I split the gumbo, étouffée a Natchitoches meat pie and a pistolette 
Super excited to find this little hole in the wall!!

data.title: Sad...
data.text: I have visited Cajun Tailgators on four different occasions. My first visit was during May 2014 and I walked away with a very happy tummy. The gumbo and boudin balls were delicious!  My second visit was during June 2014 and once again I was a happy customer.  The crawfish pistolette was amazing! I visited again during September 2014 and was disappointed.  The boudin balls were fried way too long causing them to be so dry that I could barely choke them down. The meat pie was just okay. The beignets are deep fried dinner rolls with powdered sugar - no thank you. I returned with my mom in November 2014. She ordered the shrimp poboy. Although the shrimp were few and small, she loved the bread. Given I loved it during a previous visit, I ordered a large bowl of the gumbo. Either the cook and/or the recipe had changed because this was without a doubt the nastiest tasting crud that I have ever tried to eat. First, it tasted old and rancid...like old grease smells. Second, it was so ridiculously spicy that I couldn't have enjoyed it even if it did taste good. Possibly the cook was trying to scorch my taste buds so that I couldn't tell that I was served a bowl of nasty. The crackers served with the gumbo were stale so that only made it worse. I walked out disappointed and hungry. I don't know why the steady decline in the food but I'm scared to return. A little too expensive to leave hungry. The only reason I rated a 2 versus 1 is because I know how good they can be and their customer service is above average.

data.title: Potential, but doesn't deliver!
data.text:
Tiny little place, only a few tables, which doesn't necessarily mean bad, but in this case...
The service while super friendly, was slow. The prices were high, even if the food had been good! The fried seafood we had was super salty, the Boudin Balls were gummy & bland, the Gumbo was ok, but better at Tasty Tails. We were not impressed & surely won't go back.

data.title: Not Fancy but Really Good!
data.text: This is basically a hole in the wall - which we like because they tend to have character and this place does. The staff was laid back but friendly and helpful. I had the combination plate of crawfish pistolette, fried crawfish, and crawfish etouffee.  I did not care for the pistolette (too fried for my taste) but the crawfish etouffee was excellent!!  My husband had the shrimp po boy with onion rings.  The bread for the po boy was from a bakery in New Orleans and he really enjoyed it.  The onion rings were not overly greasy.  Its also BYOB which is really nice!  We will definitely be going back!

data.title: Lacking Cajun Flavors
data.text: I really wanted to like this place but just couldn't. I had read about the food truck they have that travels around Dallas and the reviews were good. They even made # 28 on the list of 100 must eats in Dallas for their crawfish pistolette. The restaurant is located in the urban area of downtown Plano surrounded by loft apartments. It's housed in a tiny brick building that has been several other cafes previously and shows a lot of wear and tear. We arrived (2) around 2 pm and maybe the staff were tired but they seemed very lackluster and not interested in explaining the menu to us. We ordered a cup of Gumbo ($5) it was full of fire but had little flavor almost too spicy to eat, bowl of etouffee ($8) which had flavor but no heat, catfish po'boy ($10) which tasted muddy. With sodas bill was $31. Very disappointing, would not go back.
